item.content:encoded:
Our yearly celebration of the best infographics and data-visualisations from around the world is back! Now in partnership with The Data Visualisation Society, a professional home and community for those working in this discipline.

If you create in this field, you may wish to submit your work.

We welcome entries of any type: infographics, data journalism, maps, interactives, information art, video, animation, app, site, sculpture, or artwork. Entries can be created in any software, platform, or medium, using any type of materials.

There are ten categories open for submission:

» Arts, Entertainment & Culture
» Business Analytics
» Current Affairs & Politics
» Humanitarian
» Leisure, Games & Sport
» People, Language & Identity
» Places, Spaces & Environment
» Science, Technology & Health 
» 2022 Special Category: COVID-19
» Unusual

Entries are currently open and will close on Sep 18th 2022.
Any work created between Sep 1st 2019 and Aug 2022 is eligible.
» See more criteria for entry

You can see previous years’ winners and entries on the Information is Beautiful Awards Showcase.

See you at the Awards ceremony on Nov 30th?

item.title: Russian Gas – Who imports it? Who’s Dependent On it?
item.dc:creator: David McCandless
item.description: Visualising the full extent of Russia’s natural gas production & exports to understand how much the European Union is tied to Russian energy. Numbers for this chart were hard to find, scattered across various news reports and PDFs. But it clearly shows why Germany – and several other countries – will have a very difficult time weaning themselves […]
item.content:encoded:
Visualising the full extent of Russia’s natural gas production & exports to understand how much the European Union is tied to Russian energy.

Numbers for this chart were hard to find, scattered across various news reports and PDFs. But it clearly shows why Germany – and several other countries – will have a very difficult time weaning themselves off this far-reaching supply chain. Perversely, though, this may end up accelerating the global shift to renewable energy by 2050.

item.content:encoded:
200+ hand-crafted infographics and visualisations, surfacing positive trends, uplifting stats and creative solutions to the world’s problems – in handy, multi-coloured book form.

The book is also full of fresh new infographic primers and visualisations which delve deeper into certain key topics. These are designed to better arm you with context and understanding when doom-scrolling headlines and news stories about climate, or clean energies, or the plastics crisis – or any the major features of the future.
